item.title: Qué significa ‘covert’
item.description: Esta palabra ha aparecido en 339 artículos en NYTimes.com en el último año. ¿Puedes usarla en una frase?
item.dc:creator: The Learning Network

item.title: ¿La comida puede ser arte? Dinamarca lo está debatiendo
item.description: De aprobarse una nueva iniciativa, los chefs de alto nivel del país podrían optar a financiación artística. Sin embargo, no todos en el mundo del arte y la cocina brindan por la idea.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Abend

media:content.media:credit: Sergei Gapon/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Una mariposa liofilizada sobre una hoja de col rizada, perejil y espinacas y queso fresco de ortiga, en el restaurante Alchemist de Copenhague.

item.title: Word of the Day: covert
item.description: This word has appeared in 339 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
item.dc:creator: The Learning Network

item.title: Michael Kosta Blasts the Super Bowl Halftime Alternative
item.description: “Man, that is a real who’s who of ‘Who?’” Kosta mused about Turning Point USA’s concert as opposed to the halftime show led by Bad Bunny.
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: The Daily Show with Jon Stewart (TV Program)
Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)
Late Night with Seth Meyers (TV Program)

item.title: Trump Signs Bill to End Partial Government Shutdown
item.description: President Trump signed a spending package on Tuesday that reopened major parts of the government, as well as fund the Department of Homeland Security as negotiations over restrictions on the administration’s immigration crackdown continue.
item.dc:creator: Nailah Morgan

media:content.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump signing the spending package in the Oval Office on Tuesday.

item.title: Algo parecido a una buena muerte
item.description: Dicen que hay que vivir cada día como si fuera el último, y ese era justamente el plan de Brian.
item.dc:creator: John Leland

media:content.media:credit: James Adolf
media:content.media:description: Brian Cahill, en una visita reciente a casa de un amigo en el norte del estado de Nueva York. Hace unos tres años, le dijeron que le quedaban entre tres y cinco años de vida.

item.title: Juegos Olímpicos de Invierno: se recomienda paciencia para los asistentes
item.description: El evento deportivo que inicia esta semana en el norte de Italia representará un desafío logístico por las largas distancias entre sedes, las estrechas carreteras en los Alpes, la complejidad del transporte y el acecho de nevadas.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz and Alessandro Grassani

media:content.media:description: Durante la ceremonia de inauguración de la circunvalación de Tai di Cadore en la carretera estatal 51.

item.title: In Counting the Dead in Iran, a Picture of Ferocity
item.description: The high number of dead and wounded demonstrates the depths of the regime’s fears.
item.dc:creator: Scott Anderson
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: How 2026 Winter Olympics Security Is Preparing For The Opening Ceremony
item.description: Thousands of police and security officers will work during the Milan-Cortina Games’ opening ceremony. The involvement of some U.S. ICE personnel has stirred opposition.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja

media:content.media:credit: Maja Hitij/Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Italian carabinieri in Milan on Sunday. The city is hosting the Winter Olympics this month.

item.title: South Korea Questions Cram School Culture and Childhood Stress
item.description: Academic pressure has become so intense that even preschoolers are taking private extracurricular classes, raising worries about children’s rights.
item.dc:creator: Max Kim and Jean Chung

media:content.media:description: Seoul has “Therapy Zone” boxes, soundproof spaces where students can study, or vent, in the evenings after school.

item.title: ‘Neoroyalism’ and What It Says About Trump
item.description: Experts are reaching to divine the president’s approach to global policy and economics, with one theory seeing antecedents in centuries-old dynastic rule.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen

media:content.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman gave President Trump a warm and opulent welcome in Saudi Arabia last year.

item.title: Corrections: Feb. 4, 2026
item.description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Feb. 4, 2026.

item.title: Quote of the Day: Minneapolis and an Internet at War With Truth
item.description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, February 4, 2026.

item.title: How to Light a Room Like a Swede
item.description: Tips from experts who know dark winter days — and design — like no others.
item.dc:creator: Alexa Brazilian

item.title: NYT Crossword Answers for Feb. 4, 2026
item.description: Hanh Huynh and Ted Mayer make their collaboration debut in the New York Times Crossword.
item.dc:creator: Sam Corbin

item.title: Don Lemon Takes Stage at NYC Event After Arrest Over Minnesota Protest
item.description: The anchorman, who was arrested over a protest in Minnesota, told an audience in Manhattan, “I’m not going to let them turn me around,” and sang lines from a civil rights era freedom song.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Southall and Davaughnia Wilson

media:content.media:credit: Patrick T. Fallon/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Don Lemon, the former CNN anchor, was arrested last week after he covered a protest in January at a church in Minnesota.

item.title: Catherine O’Hara, Star of ‘Best in Show,’ Honored in Westminster Tribute
item.description: Fans remembered the actress, who died last week at 71, for her role as the doting owner of a Norwich terrier destined for glory in the movie, a sendup of dog show culture.
item.dc:creator: Callie Holtermann

media:content.media:credit: Doane Gregory/Online USA, via Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Catherine O’Hara as Cookie Fleck, a Florida dog lover with a past, in Christopher Guest’s “Best in Show.” Her hapless husband, Gerry (Eugene Levy), rose to the occasion in the film’s fictional dog show.

item.title: Walmart alcanza la valuación billonaria
item.description: El avance del comercio electrónico y el énfasis en la automatización y la inteligencia artificial dispararon el valor bursátil de la empresa.
item.dc:creator: Kailyn Rhone

media:content.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Tyler Robinson’s Lawyers Press to Remove Prosecutors From Kirk Murder Case
item.description: Mr. Robinson’s lawyers argue that the entire prosecution team has a conflict of interest because one prosecutor’s daughter was present when Charlie Kirk was killed.
item.dc:creator: Jack Healy

media:content.media:credit: Pool photo by Trent Nelson
media:content.media:description: Chad Grunander, a deputy Utah County attorney, testifying during a hearing in the Fourth District Court in Provo, Utah, on Tuesday.

item.title: Backed by Mamdani, D.S.A. Candidate Wins Election for Mayor’s Old Seat
item.description: Diana Moreno will serve the remainder of Mayor Zohran Mamdani’s term in the New York State Assembly in one of four special legislative elections decided on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos

media:content.media:credit: Jackie Molloy for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Diana Moreno, who was born in Ecuador, said that she would prioritize legislation to stop localities from collaborating with federal immigration agents.

item.title: Racial Debate Rattles Texas Democratic Primary for Senate
item.description: State Representative James Talarico used the word “mediocre” in connection with a former House member who is Black. The controversy has repercussions for a key contest.
item.dc:creator: J. David Goodman

media:content.media:credit: Jordan Vonderhaar for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Texas State Representative James Talarico at a town hall in New Braunfels, Texas, last month.

item.title: Trump, Changing Course, Throws Harvard Deal Talks Into Chaos
item.description: In the latest example of his mercurial negotiating style, President Trump went from dropping his ask for a $200 million fine to demanding $1 billion from the university.
item.dc:creator: Michael C. Bender, Alan Blinder, Mark Arsenault and Michael S. Schmidt

media:content.media:credit: Sophie Park for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump appeared to once again threaten to cut off Harvard from future research funding, which is the lifeblood of major research universities.

item.title: El exesposo de Jill Biden fue detenido y acusado de matar a su esposa
item.description: William Stevenson, de 77 años, fue detenido e imputado de asesinato. Aún no se conocen detalles de la muerte de su esposa Linda Stevenson de 64 años.
item.dc:creator: Billy Witz

item.title: In Ohio, I Caught a Glimpse of the New Resistance
item.description: It’s not just blue America where people are readying themselves for disaster.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Goldberg

media:content.media:credit: Taylor Dorrell for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: In Springfield, Ohio, up to a quarter of the population is Haitian.

item.title: Judge Appears Likely to Curtail Hegseth’s Power to Penalize Kelly for Video
item.description: Attorneys for Democratic Senator Mark Kelly argued that Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth was brazenly violating the separation of powers by seeking to punish a member of Congress for public statements.
item.dc:creator: Megan Mineiro

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Senator Mark Kelly, Democrat of Arizona, outside of federal court in Washington on Tuesday after a hearing in his case against the Trump administration.

item.title: Mamdani Seeks New Mission for Pro-Business Agency: Fighting for Workers
item.description: According to a Jan. 2 memo obtained by The New York Times, Mayor Zohran Mamdani wants to remake the Economic Development Corporation to address affordability and workers’ rights.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Haag and Dana Rubinstein

media:content.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: In December, Zohran Mamdani named Julie Su, right, as the city’s first ever deputy mayor for economic justice.

item.title: What Is the Democrats’ Game Plan on ICE?
item.description: After nearly four days of a partial government shutdown, the House voted to temporarily continue funding the Department of Homeland Security. Was it the right move? Times Opinion’s editor, Kathleen Kingsbury, argues that Democrats’ demands are reasonable, but they risk losing momentum before the next deadline.

item.title: Trump Repeats Call to ‘Nationalize’ Elections, as White House Walks It Back
item.description: President Trump’s extraordinary comments were the latest iteration of his unsubstantiated claims that U.S. elections are rigged as Republicans face potentially big losses next year.
item.dc:creator: Erica L. Green, Michael Gold and Robert Jimison

media:content.media:credit: Nick Hagen for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A sign directs voters in Dearborn, Mich., in November 2024.

item.title: Judge Says U.S. Has Agreed to Fix Redaction Errors in Epstein Files
item.description: Judge Richard M. Berman canceled a hearing set for Wednesday and said he was “pleased but not surprised” that the issues had been resolved to protect victims in the Jeffrey Epstein case.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Weiser

media:content.media:credit: Jon Elswick/Associated Press
media:content.media:description: A federal judge in Manhattan canceled a hearing after lawyers representing victims of Jeffrey Epstein said the government had promised to fix redaction errors in files that were recently released.

item.title: Plastic Surgeons’ Group Advises Delaying Gender-Affirming Procedures Until Age 19
item.description: The organization’s latest guidance is a departure from the prevailing views of several other major medical organizations.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Jacobs

media:content.media:credit: Morsa Images/Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Between 2016 and 2020, about 3,700 patients 18 years old and younger have undergone gender transition surgery, mostly for breast removal, according to a JAMA study.

item.title: Netflix Leader Pushes Warner Deal Before Skeptical Lawmakers
item.description: Senators asked Ted Sarandos about whether the acquisition would raise prices, squeeze talent and degrade the moviegoing experience.
item.dc:creator: David McCabe

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Ted Sarandos, left, a co-chief executive of Netflix, told a Senate subcommittee on Tuesday that “we’ll keep growing the American entertainment industry.”

item.title: Stephen Miran Resigns From White House as Fed Term Stretches On
item.description: Mr. Miran had taken a leave of absence from advising the president after adding a role at the Federal Reserve, drawing criticism from Democrats.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith and Tony Romm
item.category: White House Council of Economic Advisers

media:content.media:credit: Amir Hamja for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Stephen Miran, who is resigning as chair of the Council of Economic Advisers, can continue to serve as a Federal Reserve governor until a replacement is confirmed.

item.title: Seif al-Islam el-Qaddafi, Son of Libyan Dictator, Is Killed
item.description: Mr. el-Qaddafi, 53, a politician and a son of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, was killed after four men stormed his house, the lawyer said. No other details were released.
item.dc:creator: Islam Al-Atrash and Ephrat Livni

media:content.media:credit: Moises Saman for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Seif al-Islam el-Qaddafi gave an interview to The New York Times in Tripoli, Libya, in 2011.

item.title: Trump Scolds CNN’s Kaitlan Collins for ‘Not Smiling’
item.description: Testy remarks from a president who has frequently singled out female journalists for criticism and personal attacks.
item.dc:creator: Michael M. Grynbaum

media:content.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: CNN’s Kaitlan Collins, center, asks President Donald Trump a question in the Oval Office in November.

item.title: Renee Good’s Brothers Call on Congress to Rein In Immigration Crackdown
item.description: At a forum on Capitol Hill held by congressional Democrats, the brothers of the 37-year-old American citizen fatally shot by an ICE agent said immigration enforcement tactics must be dialed back.
item.dc:creator: Michael Gold
item.category: House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Brothers of Renee Good, Luke Ganger, left, and Brent Ganger, during a public forum at the Capitol in Washington on Tuesday.

item.title: India Walton Will Return to Politics to Oppose Hochul as Delgado’s No. 2
item.description: Lt. Gov. Antonio Delgado’s choice of Ms. Walton may strengthen his bid to position himself as a left-leaning alternative to Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Oreskes

media:content.media:credit: Brendan Bannon for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: India Walton has not run for public office since 2023, when she lost the Democratic primary for the Buffalo, N.Y., Common Council.

item.title: Grammy Awards Audience Declines by a Million Viewers
item.description: The show on Sunday drew about 14.4 million people. It is the second consecutive year that the awards ceremony attracted a smaller audience.
item.dc:creator: John Koblin

media:content.media:credit: Kevin Winter/Getty Images for The Recording Academy
media:content.media:description: Bruno Mars performing at the Grammy Awards on Sunday. As recently as 2024, the show had nearly 17 million viewers.

item.title: El fideicomiso de Epstein revela quién heredaría su fortuna
item.description: Un documento que fue dado a conocer junto con millones de páginas de archivos de investigación hizo pública una lista de unas 40 personas como posibles beneficiarios.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Goldstein

media:content.media:credit: vía House Oversight Democrats
media:content.media:description: No está claro cuánto recibirán los beneficiarios de la herencia de Jeffrey Epstein. El valor de esta ha descendido significativamente desde su muerte, debido al pago de impuestos, honorarios de abogados y acuerdos con las víctimas de sus abusos sexuales.

item.title: Meat Processors Take a Hit as Cattle Prices Remain High
item.description: Tyson Foods said its beef business could lose up to $500 million this year as the supply of cattle reaches a 75-year low.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Draper

media:content.media:credit: Carlos Barria/Reuters
media:content.media:description: Tyson Foods is among the companies struggling with the cost of beef, as the U.S. cattle supply remains at its lowest level since 1951.

item.title: Westminster Dog Show Highlights: Penny, a Statuesque Doberman Pinscher, Captures Best in Show
item.description: Penny, 4, is lithe and easygoing, with a rich, shiny black coat. She beat out a silky-haired Afghan hound, an exuberant Old English sheepdog and a sprightly smooth fox terrier.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

media:content.media:credit: Lanna Apisukh for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Cota (above, with his handler, Devon Kipp Levy) bested his fellow athletes in the sporting group to be named best in group.

item.title: Trump Releases Latest Rendering of White House Ballroom Project
item.description: President Trump emphasized that the ballroom would not be taller than the Executive Mansion of the White House, as he faces criticism over the size of the project.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater

media:content.media:credit: Donald Trump, via Truth Social
media:content.media:description: A rendering released by President Trump shows the latest design for a large ballroom on White House grounds.

item.title: Westminster Presbyterian Church in Minneapolis Is a Place for Protest
item.description: In the weeks since ICE agents began conducting operations across the city, Westminster Presbyterian has given its members a place to protest on their own terms.
item.dc:creator: Claire Fahy

media:content.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Westminster Presbyterian Church in Minneapolis on Monday. It was founded in 1857 and has found purpose in its city’s crisis.

item.title: The Shutdown Is Over, but Not the Clash Over ICE Funding
item.description: Also, colleges saw notable racial shifts in student enrollment. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen

media:content.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times

item.title: Renee Good’s Relatives Speak to Lawmakers in Washington
item.description: Two brothers of Ms. Good, who was shot by a federal agent last month, expressed disappointment that her death had not led to changes in enforcement tactics. Minnesota’s governor called for restrictions on immigration operations at schools.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
